text: when the u.s. gathered the leaders of
Israel and the Palestinians to sign the
Oslo Accords in the 1990s their first
peace agreement
prominent among the peacemakers was
Shimon Peres it never lived up to the
early promise but at the time no one
articulated that promise better than
Peres what we are doing today is more
than signing an agreement it is a
revolution yesterday a dream today a
commitment she won't pose judicially
Shimon dedicated his life to the
sovereignty of our people as a man of
vision he was always looking to the
future as a man of security he fortified
Israel's strengths in ways we are only
just beginning to understand as a man of
peace he worked until his final days for
the reconciliation with our neighbors
for a better future for our children
Dalila done his work on the deal won him
the Nobel Peace Prize a fitting accolade
for a man who was more popular on the
world stage than he was with his own
country's voters Shimon Peres was born
in Poland and came to the Holy Land as a
child in the 1930s as the founding
leader David ben-gurion shaped the new
Israeli state Paris was a backroom
operator working on the arms deals and
agreements that made Israel of
formidable military power in that role
he became father of Israel's nuclear
program the reactor at Damona was built
largely thanks to his negotiating skills
but he had many other jobs too Israelis
celebrated his main achievement as
Minister of Defense in 1976 the daring
commando raid on the airport at Entebbe
in Uganda to free Israeli hostages held
at gunpoint by Palestinian and German
hijackers this was a nun president an
unprecedented operation
since it was the longest from the point
of view of range they shouted from the
point of view of time and their most
daring one can imagine as times changed
in the course of a long life shimon
peres changed opinions - he was once
part of a government that approved
jewish settlements on the occupied
Palestinian territory of the West Bank
but he came to see them as an obstacle
to peace that degree of flexibility
never seemed to be quite while his
Rayleigh voters were looking for in a
man who was a technocrat rather than a
retired general like some of his rivals
he was never to win an election
outright although he did serve twice
briefly as Prime Minister but the long
career of Shimon Peres had an
extraordinary final act he was still
serving in the largely ceremonial
presidency after his 90th birthday
the oldest head of state in the world at
the time he was still thinking of the
future - hoping for peace but arguing
that peace could only be made that the
country that he served remained strong
